turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Attack at Fromelles.
turn.1: What were the main causes of the First World War mass graves at Fromelles?
turn.2: From 2008, an exploratory dig found human remains, personal effects, webbing, brass fitments, uniform badges, buttons and British .303 ammunition in five of six pits, which were then refilled.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: Exhumations took place from May to September 2009, which recovered the mortal remains of soldiers, approximately 173 of whom were Australian, from which DNA samples were taken.
turn.6: The original burial site was unsuitable and a new CWGC war cemetery was built about away.
turn.7: What else happened during this event?
turn.8: On 30 January 2010, the first body was interred at Fromelles (Pheasant Wood) Military Cemetery and the remaining bodies were buried in individual ceremonies, by the Royal Regiment of Fusiliers and the Australian Army.
turn.10: In March 2010, it was reported that soldiers killed at Fromelles had been identified from DNA.
turn.11: What else happened during this event?
turn.12: On 19 July 2010, the 94th anniversary of the battle, the last soldier (who remained unknown) was buried.
